results.title: A Woman under the influence
results.creator_credit: John Cassavetes, Sam Shaw and Faces International Films Inc
results.brief_description: The title of this film refers to a wife and mother, Mabel Longhetti, who moves completely under the influence of her family and other people. She tries so hard to perform and conform, according to what she perceives they want, but she just comes across as “crazy” and the family are embarrassed. In the confusion, the film makes Mabel an expressive centre, focusing on the commotion she causes and the forms of agitation that extend across her face and body.

results.title: The Killing of a Chinese bookie
results.creator_credit: John Cassavetes, Al Ruban and Faces Distribution Corporation
results.brief_description: The Killing of a Chinese Bookie presents a portrait of a man who is so self-sufficient that he cannot become personally involved with anyone. Cosmo Vitelli, played by Ben Gazzara, is a nightclub owner who believes in conducting his personal and business affairs with plenty of flair and professionalism. When the mob threatens him he works desperately to save his face and the club.

results.title: Faces
results.creator_credit: John Cassavetes, Maurice McEndree and Walter Reade Organization
results.brief_description: Faces concentrates on two scenarios, one where middle-aged businessmen cheat on their wives and the other where the wives bring home a younger man from a nightclub. Both wives and husbands take turns in testing the novelty of the situations, initially improvising to bridge the awkwardness but then risking more and more. While the night out feels liberating, it ends up tearing painfully at their conservative personas.

results.title: Shadows
results.creator_credit: John Cassavetes, Maurice McEndree and Cassavetes, McEndree, Cassel Productions
results.brief_description: ‘Shadows’ was a vanguard work of the independent American cinema, a bittersweet comedy centred on three African-American outsiders - Lelia and his two jazz-musicians brothers living in Greenwich Village - two of whom pass for white and all are part of the late fifties ‘lost generation’. We follow Lelia through three brief romantic involvements. Although the film was recognised at the time for its treatment of race, Cassavetes saw this as incidental to the wider question of identity. His special commitment to expression through performance and a concomitant openness of form give his films a rough, uninflected, anecdotal quality (a form of ‘fictional cinema verite’). ‘Shadows’, like other Cassavetes’ films was fully scripted despite the reference in the end title to the film as ‘an improvisation’. Cast includes Lelia Goldoni, Ben Carruthers, Hugh Hurd.

results.title: A Life less ordinary
results.creator_credit: Danny Boyle, Andrew Macdonald and Figment Films
results.brief_description: Acclaimed “Trainspotting” trio (director Danny Boyle, producer Andrew Macdonald, and screenwriter John Hodge) re-unite for this wacky romantic comedy. Two angels, O’Reilly (Holly Hunter) and Jackson (Delroy Lindo) are assigned to make two people fall in love. If they fail the angels will be stuck on earth forever. The targets of this matchmaking mission are Celine (Cameron Diaz), a heartless, rich woman with a penchant for guns, and Robert (Ewan McGregor), an aspiring pulp novelist who works as a janitor in the corporation owned by Celine’s father (Ian Holm). When Robert is sacked and replaced by a robot a chain of events begins which brings the two together. Robert attempts to kidnap Celine and get his job back, and Celine attempts to make Robert extort money from her father. Meanwhile angels O’Reilly and Jackson are working overtime to get Robert and Celine to fall in love, which isn’t easy seeing as the two mismatched kidnappers create chaos wherever they go. A quirky adventure romance, “A Life less ordinary” races along with a great soundtrack and moments of pure madness and fantasy (look out for the song and dance routine between Ewan McGregor and Cameron Diaz).

results.title: Reality bites
results.creator_credit: Ben Stiller, Michael Shamberg, Danny DeVito and Jersey Films
results.brief_description: Reality Bites is Ben Stiller’s directorial debut, and one of the more mainstream offerings in the array of films that emphasized the “Generation X” phenomenon. Lelaina is a recent college graduate out on her own and independent from her supportive, but out-of-touch parents, facing the realities of careers and relationships in the adult world. She can’t stand her internship under a local television personality, and is forced to choose between Michael, a well-intentioned music-video network executive, and Troy, a brooding, sensitive slacker. Meanwhile, she must also protect the artistic integrity of her video documentary that depicts the everyday lives of her friends and herself. Cast includes: Winona Ryder, Ethan Hawke, Ben Stiller, Janeane Garofalo and Steve Zahn.

results.title: The Life of Oharu = Saikaku ichidai onna
results.creator_credit: Kenji Mizoguchi, Hideo Koi, Koi and Shintoho Eiga
results.brief_description: ‘The Life of Oharu’ is an adaptation of Saikaku’s classic novel which traces the tragic riches to rags life of a Japanese woman in 17th century Japan. Told in the form of flashback, the film begins with an elderly Oharu praying before Buddha, reflecting on her life, and her first love. Years ago the well respected Oharu fell in love with a samurai (played by a young Toshiro Mifune), only to lose favour with her family who are exiled for her actions, as well as her love who is promptly beheaded. Her father forces her to become mistress of a great lord in order to bear him an heir, which she does, but is abandoned by the prince after she gives birth. Outcast by the prince, Oharu slides to the lowest rank in society and is forced into becoming a prostitute and beggar. Her life is populated by love and servitude to the men she encounters, as well as the knowledge that her royal son is the one chance she has at escaping her life of poverty and humiliation. The sufferings of the beautiful Oharu (Kinuyo Tanaka) are observed without sentimentality or moralising by Mizoguchi who is acknowledged as being a lifelong advocate of equitable treatment for Japanese women. In Japanese with English subtitles. Cast also includes Ichiro Sugai, Toshiro Yanane and Ataro Shindo.

results.title: This happy breed
results.creator_credit: David Lean, Cineguild Production and Noel Coward
results.brief_description: This affectionate tribute to the ordinary man is a panoramic story of the life of a London family during the two World Wars. Based on Noel Coward’s successful play (he also wrote the musical score), the film chronicles the Gibbons family from 1919 to 1939, and was released during the Second World War as part of the British film industry’s war effort. Robert Newton and Celia Johnson are Frank and Ethel Gibbons who, with their daughters Queenie (Kay Walsh) and Phyllis (Betty Fleetwood), face the day to day crises of ordinary life to survive as both individuals and as a family. Stanley Holloway and a very young John Mills star in this production along with narrator Laurence Olivier.

results.title: Through the olive trees
results.creator_credit: Abbas Kiarostami, Farabi Cinema Foundation and Abbas Kiarostami Productions (film company)
results.brief_description: Iranian cinema in the last two decades of the twentieth century has proved to be one of few national cinemas offering an alternative to the dominance of Hollywood, both in terms of production and in terms of aesthetics. Kiarostami is one of the leading directors of post-revolutionary Iranian cinema and his work is intimately concerned with both the nature of human relationships and the power of cinema to influence and transform life. A film crew arrives in a small town devastated by a recent earthquake. Hossein, a young and homeless bricklayer is given a small role as a newly wed husband. The woman who is to play his wife is Tahereh, the girl he adores but who refuses to have anything to do with him. As the director attempts to get the two young people to play their roles in the script, Tahereh and Hossein enact their own drama and conflict in front of the camera. From this simple material, Kiarostami explores the tensions between men and women, reality and imagination, film and politics, and allows us as an audience to explore the ability of film as an art to seduce us even when it is lying to us. Without the use of special effects, big budgets or imaginary beings, “Through the Olive Trees” transports us to a magical world of human drama that Hollywood could not possibly emulate, no matter how much money or technology lies at its disposal.

results.title: The Lodger
results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock, Carlyle Blackwell Sr, Sir Michael Balcon and Gainsborough Pictures
results.brief_description: While ‘The Lodger’ was not director Alfred Hitchcock’s first film, it was the first to truly deserve the designation “A Hitchcock Picture”. British matinee idol Ivor Novello plays Jonathan Drew, a quiet, secretive young man who rents a room in a London boarding house. Drew’s arrival coincides with the reign of terror orchestrated by Jack the Ripper. As the film progresses, circumstantial evidence begins to mount, pointing to Drew as the selfsame Ripper. In the original story by Mrs Belloc-Lownes, suspicions concerning Drew were confirmed; but Ivor Novello was a star of the first magnitude, and stars of the first magnitude just didn’t play murderers back in 1926. Thus, we learn at the last possible moment that Drew is innocent, and is in fact on the trail of the Ripper himself. Hitchcock makes his cameo appearance at a desk in the newsroom early in the film. Some people claim he also appears later in the crowd watching the arrest. Hitchcock wanted an ambiguous ending to the film, but the studio wouldn’t allow it to be implied that Ivor Novello might actually be the murderer.
